awd_titl_txt: Ecological determinants of luteal reproductive function
awd_abstract_narration:
The causes of miscarriage, an often devastating event that occurs not infrequently in women's reproductive lives, are poorly understood.  What is known is that the luteal phase of early pregnancy (the time of conception and implantation) is not only critically important to successful reproduction, it also is the phase which is the first to be suppressed when women experience stress. This research utilizes an anthropological approach to place female reproductive functioning and the spectrum of variation in luteal phase biology between women into an ecological and developmental context, focusing on a human population under moderate levels of energetic and immune function stress.  The results will illuminate the causal factors relating to human variation in the luteal phase and the resulting impacts on reproduction, which are poorly  understood.

This project will promote greater understanding by studying the endometrium, the site of embryo implantation and thus important to luteal phase and miscarriage research. By focusing on a non-western population in rural Poland, a comparative perspective is gained which can promote understanding of why American women experience reproductive disorders more than people in other countries. The approach places the endometrium in a broader context of the stressors experienced by women living under variable ecological stressors that may suppress its ability to support pregnancy. It also is the first-ever study of women?s systemic reproductive functioning over an entire menstrual cycle, since it includes daily urine collection for analysis of reproductive hormones and stress biomarkers, alongside ultrasound of the endometrium, demographic data, and bodily measurements of the women in this population.

     This population-level research therefore will characterize the relationship between the ovaries and endometrium in an energetically and immunologically stressed, agricultural environment; study the associations between these stressors and luteal function; and provide a longitudinal  perspective which can explore how developmental milestones like birth weight and age at first menstruation influence luteal function. Once baseline, normal variation in the luteal ovaries and endometrium is analyzed, future studies will be able to more fully illuminate how stressors could affect the maternal environment and drive miscarriage. The work promotes understanding of human biology far beyond what can be gained in a clinical study, yet has clinical applications for the development of safer and more effective personalized hormonal contraceptives that consider age, childhood conditions and lifestyle in their dosing structure. It also will advance scientific discovery via a structured mentoring program for underrepresented students, incorporation of the research into introductory and advanced coursework, and by widely disseminating this anthropological perspective and research results to the general public using the PI's standing as an award-winning blogger at Scientific American.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Over the last four years, we have had the pleasure of conducting three field seasons in rural Poland, developing and testing a new multiplex assay to allow even deeper analysis of our samples, and starting to analyze and present our results to our peers.

The major goal of this project is to increase our understanding of luteal reproductive function, as it is the first component of reproductive function to experience constraint from ecological stressors, and also the period during which conception and implantation occur. My aims were:

  • Aim 1: Characterize the relationship between ovarian and endometrial function among women in a moderately constrained environment.
  • Aim 2: Model the associations between biomarkers of ecological stressors and ovarian and endometrial function.
  • Aim 3: Advance our understanding of how developmental milestones correlate with adult reproductive function.

While the endometrium, the lining of the uterus, is crucial to processes of implantation and placentation in early pregnancy, we know little of its normal range of variation across human environments. We still don?t have a particularly holistic view of all the things that happen in the uterus during the menstrual cycle, when trying to conceive, and during conception and implantation. And we don?t know the ways in which the endometrium during the menstrual cycle might contribute to a higher or lower probability of conception, implantation, or miscarriage.

This project has succeeded in collecting up to three ultrasound measurements of the endometrium through the second half of the cycle. We have also conducted quantitative ultrasound analyses of these endometrial images. Preliminary results suggest that women with lower estradiol early in their cycles, or shorter luteal phases, have thinner endometria. Now that our labwork is complete we should be able to look at hormones and inflammatory and psychosocial stress biomarkers and how they correspond to endometrial thickness.

Thanks to the involvement of some spectacular trainees, our project went in some interesting directions and we have made some additional discoveries. We have found support for what?s called the ?secular trend of age at menarche? in the rural region of Poland where we conduct our research. Over the last few decades of work there, women have reported increasingly early ages at first period, to the point that they are only a little older than US girls when they first menstruate (Fig. 1).

We have also found that women who helped with farmwork as children have later ages at menarche and lower estradiol in adulthood. This is significant for two reasons: farmwork is energetically taxing, but it also introduces people to immune challenges from soil microbes and farm animals. So we suspect that energetic and immune stressors early in life influence age at menarche and adult reproductive function (Fig. 2 & 3).

We managed to secure other funding that allowed us to collect a comparative sample of Polish-American women, and found that third generation and later Polish-Americans had longer luteal phases. Additional work on the hormones and biomarkers will soon tell us if there are other major differences between these groups. This provides further evidence towards the idea that one?s childhood environment influences later reproductive function.

Finally, thanks to the NSF we had so much data to manage and labwork to do that we were able to significantly expand our undergraduate mentoring and research opportunities. In the last few years we teamed up with the Illinois Researchers Initiative, which brought in up to five new underrepresented students to our lab every spring. Many of those students enjoyed their experience so much that they stayed with our lab even when their RI experience was over; still others persisted in science and joined other labs. We?ve become one of the most popular labs in the RI program and enjoy the vibrancy and curiosity undergraduates bring to our lab meetings.


Last Modified: 12/12/2018
Modified by: Kathryn B Clancy

Images (1 of )
  • This image shows the change in the last few decades with menarcheal age in the rural Polish population we study.
    Mary Rogers
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Kathryn B Clancy
    Figure 1. Secular trend in age at menarche
  • This image shows that whether or not women participated in farmwork as children is related to when they reach menarche.
    Mary Rogers
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Kathryn B Clancy
    Figure 2. Childhood farming and age at menarche
  • This image shows that whether or not women participated in farmwork as children is related to their adult estradiol concentrations. We measure estradiol metabolites in urine, in order to measure hormones noninvasively.
    Mary Rogers
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Kathryn B Clancy
    Figure 3. Childhood farming and estradiol metabolite concentrations.
